title: Thursday, 22nd June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Good morning

PM11:01am

But I'm aware I'm really not needed

PM11:01am

Bryce -- you pretty much handled ML all by yourself -- for a month!

11:01 am
PM11:01am

And it was brilliant -- the transcripts I read

PM11:01am

So...

PM11:01am

Bye

11:01 am
PM11:01am

But seriously...

PM11:02am

What'd I miss?

PM11:02am

Mayhem, clearly

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Not sure where to go here, immediately

PM11:02am

Still catching up

PM11:03am

Like Trump, who has come up with the idea of a solar wall

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Thumbs up

PM11:03am

He clearly doesn't read Alphaville

PM11:03am

Otherwise he would have read Bryce on the subject

11:03 am
PM11:03am

https://ftalphavil...-powered/?mhq5j=e2

PM11:03am

That's a very funny read

PM11:04am

Even if it was painful for you Bryce

11:04 am
BE11:04am

To be fair, he's very welcome to question my working. I'd imagine a Wharton graduate would approach the calculations with more exactitude than I.

BE11:06am

It's worth reiterating the point, though, that very few people live near the (north side) of the wall and the US doesn't have the means to push power over long distances, which'd take a humongous investment to fix.

BE11:06am

You could build a wall on all four sides of the US for the cost of a few power lines attaching Texas to Ohio.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Anyway, yes, there's that.

PM11:07am

hmm

undefined
11:07 am
PM11:07am

But let's more to the real world

PM11:07am

Footsie off 33 points

PM11:07am

It's been a bit worse earlier today

11:08 am
PM11:08am

(Groundhog -- i only got back into the country yesterday...)

BE11:08am

Slightly ex-div. Land Secs, Experian, UUs, possibly more that I didn't write down.

BE11:09am

And in terms of corporate news, Imagination's already mentioned.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

(@doodle: one person I spoke to did suggest putting free plugs and mobile chargers on the south side as an incentive to not vandalise.)

Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 145.00, up 21.5 (+17.41%), High: 149.50, Low: 141.00, Volume: 6.96m
BE11:10am

A somewhat inevitable statement, really.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

It's been unofficially for sale for some time.

PM11:10am

Simply gone formal

PM11:10am

Rothschild handling the sale I see

11:10 am
PM11:11am

And the Panel rules give all the potential bidders cover

BE11:11am

The MIPS and Ensigma businesses were put up for sale in May. Not a surprise that those talks have extended to the bit of the business that might actually have some value.

BE11:11am

Even if that value is litigation based.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Going to quote Alphavalue here, partly because I don't think we ever have before.

BE11:12am

This announcement is all but a surprise: when it was announced that Apple would stop using the company’s products, we highlighted the fact that it would be very hard for the company to survive a long and costly legal procedure, given its important cost base. With Apple as the main customer, the company was totally dependent on its stream of revenues, which had already resulted into restructuring when sales dropped last year.

BE11:12am

However, the company’s IP remains very strong, which could raise an interest amongst several potential buyers, and notably its MIPS business (acquired in 2012, competing with ARM and still used for many applications) and PowerVR technology, one of the few main graphic IPs available on the market at a time when this type of product is becoming increasingly popular beyond its traditional use (cf. Nvidia using its GPUs as super calculators for autonomous driving).

11:12 am
BE11:12am

We see this PowerVR architecture as the jewel in the crown which will attract the most interest. However, coming to an accurate valuation is rather difficult: while we had set a NAV multiple of 8x in April (based on 2017-19e revenues), corresponding at that time to a more than decent upside, equivalent to an acquisition premium, the recent rally consequent to TsingHua (the powerful Chinese government’s semiconductor arm) entering the company’s shareholding proved us wrong, or at least much more pessimistic.

BE11:12am

Now, it is more than probable that the final price will come in at a higher price range than the c. 125p we had in mind; however, it is yet to be seen if the company will be sold in pieces or as a whole, which could greatly impact the final price. Still, it is unlikely, in our view, to reach the same multiples as the acquisition of ARM by Softbank did, as Imagination is nowhere near in terms of market dominance and must face the competition of Qualcomm in the mobile GPU market.

BE11:12am

We are comfortable with our fundamental valuation, leading to no change in our hypothesis, as we enter a speculative area. However, we will boost our premium (from 30% to 50%) over peers to reflect this speculative pressure, but the impact is likely to be limited as the main valuation drivers are the DCF and the NAV (for a combined 80%).

11:12 am
PM11:13am

So who is going to buy it?

PM11:13am

The Chinese will try, surely

BE11:13am

Dunno. You'll remember TsingHua selling down last week.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(Well, you won't. The readers might.)

PM11:13am

Missed that

PM11:13am

Obv

11:14 am
BE11:14am

We're probably not looking at Apple, which could've bought Imagination at any point over the past decade and it would've been a rounding error on its petty cash tin.

BE11:14am

It's chosen another path and that's that.

BE11:14am

So ... oh, here's Stifel.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Although no individual move has as yet emerged as due likely we cannot at this point dismiss the potential for a bidding battle between prospective buyers. We think the most likely interest will come from parties most capable of cross platform rollouts (mobile, wearables, IoT, automotive, etc) utilising silicon IP in a self-directed ecosystem. This could include a co-ordinated Chinese bid, a hyper-scale vendor from the cloud or some other IP player. As a result of this announcement we shift our rating from Sell to Hold with a target price of 125p for the time being. We highlight no change to our estimates.

BE11:15am

(@Fatdaz: nope. Sold out a few years ago.)

BE11:15am

I wonder what "a hyper-scale vendor from the cloud" is? It sounds very dramatic.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

N+1 Singer too.

BE11:16am

Actually, not Singer. That's just a maintenance upgrade. Have Liberum.

BE11:17am

The companies which we think would be interested in buying Imagination include the following :

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Intel - Intel is spending $15bn to buy Mobileye to improve its position in automated driving. However, all of Mobileye's vision processors are based on MIPS IP. This includes its forthcoming EyeQ5 which will sell into the next decade. Intel, therefore, has a clear interest in supporting MIPS and its future roadmap. Intel is also falling well behind Nvidia and AMD in graphics capability and IPR. The acquisition of PowerVR will help strengthen its internal graphics team and patents.

Mediatek - Mediatek has recently started moving its high-end solutions to PowerVR. It is also beginning to move its basebands to MIPS from ARM, and sees the multi-threading capability of MIPS as an asset in 5G modems. An acquisition of Imagination by Tsinghua/Spreadtrum would be negative for Mediatek.

CEVA - CEVA was outbid by Imagination for MIPS five years ago. MIPS, PowerVR and Ensigma will be valuable additions to CEVA's strong position in DSP IP. We see CEVA as the most natural home for Imagination's IP, but the company may not have deep enough pockets for a successful bid.

Qualcomm - Qualcomm is in a major spat with Apple which fundamentally questions its longer term licensing model. An acquisition of Imagination could be an additional weapon in its fight with Apple, given the existing dispute between Imagination and Apple. Qualcomm would also see value in Imagination's ray tracing IP, while MIPS would be a useful asset in addressing many product segments including autos.

Apple - While Imagination does not have the resources to litigate with Apple, Apple would be vulnerable to significant litigation if Imagination is bought by Qualcomm or an IP troll. We also believe Apple will see value in all three IP blocks as well as Imagination's team of engineers.

Chinese entities - There are a number of entities in China which could buy Imagination including Tsing Hua, JAC Capital, Wise Road Capital, Datang Technology, Grand Chip investment etc. However, there could be issues with regulatory approval for an acquisition by a Chinese entity, perhaps more on the MIPS side.

In addition to the above, there could be other potential bidders including IP trolls, Google, Softbank, Samsung and many others.

BE11:17am

They're on for a bidding war and a premium exit.

BE11:19am

Which seems a brave argument for a company that's in a legal battle with its cornerstone customer and doesn't offer anything particularly unique versus Arm, for instance, which has Mali to push.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

We calculate a bearish and a bullish outcome based on a value of 5x EV/sales and 8x EV/sales. The low-end is in-line with the historical trading range of Imagination prior to the Apple announcement, while the high-end is in-line with the trading range of peers like CEVA (currently at 10.9x). Previous semiconductor IP acquisition's excluding that of ARM averaged 9.1x EV/sales, with ARM being acquired at 20x. We are using the expected sales of Imagination excluding those to Apple in our calculation. We are also adding a conservative estimate for the eventual settlement value with Apple in our calculation.

PM11:19am

You know the phrase "hyper-scale vendor from the cloud" has never previously been written, according to Google

BE11:19am

!

11:19 am
PM11:19am

So, to answer your question -- who knows?

BE11:20am

Last word to Campling at Northern Trust.

BE11:20am

What price could Imagination go for is anyone’s guess. The total enterprise value of just £450M today would not be a difficult consideration for cash rich U.S. technology companies. GPU architecture is critical for applications such as VR and AR which require higher graphics resolutions and frame rates and emerging applications such as ADAS and machine intelligence. However, when your main customer has basically walked away from your architecture then it’s a pretty damning assessment of the company’s technology progress in our view.

11:20 am
undefined
PM11:21am

So, cos I was 8k miles away, it was difficult to know how serious the mayhem was here while I was away

PM11:21am

And so I don't know how "normal" this is...

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Albert Edwards calling for riots against the Bank of England

PM11:21am

He's gone the full Wolfie Smith

PM11:21am

Citizen Edwards

11:21 am
PM11:22am

I'm normally careful about what we post here from Edwards

PM11:22am

Cos he complains

PM11:22am

But on this I will give you the full summary

11:22 am
PM11:22am

While politics in the West reels from a decade of economic crisis and stagnation, asset prices continue to surge on the back of continued rapid growth in G3 QE. In an age of “radical uncertainty” how long will it be before angry citizens tire of blaming an impotent political system for their ills and turn on the main culprits for their poverty – unelected and virtually unaccountable central bankers? I expect central bank independence will be (and should be) the next casualty of the current political turmoil.

PM11:23am

Evidence of the impact of monetary madness on assets prices is all around if we care to look. I read that a parking spot in Hong Kong was just sold for record HK$5.18 million ($664,200) - link! What about the 3.5x oversubscribed 100 year Argentine government bond? Sure, everything has a market clearing price, even one of the most regular defaulters in history. But what concerned me most about the story was it was demand from investors (”reverse enquires”) that prompted the issue. Is it just me or can I hear echoes of the mechanics of the CDO crisis? But no one cares when the party is still raging and investors, drunk with the liquor of loose money, are blind to the inevitable catastrophe that lies ahead.

PM11:23am

here is a lot of anger out on the streets, as demonstrated most visibly in recent elections. Even in France where investors feel comforted that a ‘moderate’ has gained (absolute?) power, it is salutary to remember that the two establishment parties have just been decimated by a man who had never before stood for public office! This is perhaps even more radical than Trump’s anti-establishment victory under the Republican umbrella. The global political situation is incredibly fluid and unpredictable. While a furious electorate has turned its pent up anger on the establishment political parties, the target for their rage is misguided. I am not completely alone in thinking it is the unelected and virtually unaccountable central bankers who are primarily responsible for the poverty of working people and who will be ultimately held to account in the next crisis.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

In the immediate aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis, politicians skilfully diverted the publics’ anger away from themselves by scapegoating ‘the bankers’. After another eight years of economic stagnation that excuse no longer is tenable and politicians themselves are now taking the flak. But citizen revolutionaries will, I think, soon turn their fire on those who I believe are truly responsible for their plight. We explained back in January 2010 in a note entitled Theft! Were the US & UK central banks complicit in robbing the middle classes? how central banks in the US and UK had deliberately stocked up massive housing bubbles prior to the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) to disguise the rapid rise in income inequality in both countries. Rapidly rising house prices allowed the middle classes to maintain the illusion they were getting richer so that despite stagnant real incomes they could continue to consume by extracting housing equity. We know how that party ended!

PM11:23am

After the GFC central bankers have collectively spent the last decade stepping up the pace of money printing to new extremes in an attempt to drown the global economy in liquidity, while couching their actions in plausible theories such as ‘secular stagnation’. There is no recognition at all by central bankers that it may well be their own easy money and zero interest rate policies that are actually causing the stagnation in growth while at the same time wealth inequality surges to intolerable heights. Yellen et al will inevitably be sacrificed at the altar of political expediency as citizen rage explodes.

PM11:23am

There's lots more to that

11:23 am
PM11:23am

But you'll need to be an SG client to read it

PM11:24am

Although, I should report that it concludes with a Zerohedge quote

PM11:24am

As Zero Hedge points out, “It is safe to say that none of these recommendations will be adopted by the career economists at the Fed.”. In my opinion the sooner a new leader is imposed at the top of the Fed (and Bank of England), the better. In any case, as the next crisis unfolds central bank independence will become a historical relic. And if that is all the citizen revolutionaries demand, politicians will consider themselves very lucky indeed!

11:24 am
undefined
BE11:25am

Okay, while you were doing that I had the chance to check my emails.

BE11:25am

Something I've not had the opportunity to do between 11am and midday for the past month.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And .... well, I guess we need to do a line or two on this.

BE11:26am

"This" being Oclaro.

BE11:26am

US-listed optical components business that was once known as Bookham Technology.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

There's been gossip around it, as many of you will know.

BE11:26am

That gossip now seems to have reached the one-man-band, "just chuck the gossip up and worry about market abuse later" blogs.

BE11:26am

That we'll not link to, because no. Just no.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

No.

PM11:27am

Omg smile

BE11:27am

The idea -- totally unsubstantiated but being being dropped into the market anyway, because whatever eh? -- is that Oclaro has received approaches that have led it to bring in advisors.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Finisar Corp and Albemarle Corp mentioned as possible buyers. Claim is that things are advanced enough to conclude at the end of June.

BE11:27am

So. We have checked this out already.

BE11:27am

A lot. Like, we've been badgering people on this story for at least a week.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And while we're not totally convinced it's wrong, we're not confident it's right either.

BE11:28am

To flesh it out, the specific rumour here -- which is a rumour! -- is that Albermarle approached Oclaro about its lithium business. Oclaro then brought in a big American bank to advise.

PM11:00am

Yeah, I'm back

11:28 am
BE11:29am

That's what's been talked about. Might be right but we've no reason right now to believe it is. And the people we've spoken to have not been helpful with our understanding of the facts.

BE11:29am

So all I can do is note that, as a rumour, it looks a bit odd.

BE11:29am

Oclaro makes lithium niobate modulators. Widgets that phase the amplitude of high-speed optical links to pack more information in without increasing the signal frequency.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Lithium is hot right now because Tesla. It's a battery play mostly, so has gone skyward with the whole electric vehicle thing.

BE11:29am

Capacity utilisation's running at 100% and the price of lithium carbonate went from $7k a tonne to $27k a tonne in the first half of last year.

BE11:29am

In that context, why would Albemarle want to spend $2bn on an optical switch maker?

11:29 am
BE11:30am

I've no idea. Maybe it makes sense, just not to me.

BE11:30am

I'd also note that, since mid May, volume in July and August out-of-the-money Oclaro calls has been peculiarly high.

BE11:30am

Which could mean that shrewd people know things.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Or it could mean they thought they knew things, but now worried that they might be wrong, and are very keen to get the story out.

PM11:30am

hmm

BE11:30am

However, I'm not here to speculate on why things end up on one-man-band, "just chuck the gossip up and worry about market abuse later" blogs.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Best of luck to all holders though. Including holders of the derivatives, I guess.

undefined
PM11:31am

Goodness, I'm un-ML-fit

11:31 am
BE11:32am

It does take a few days to get up to pace.

PM11:32am

Last time I took a sabbatical was the summer of 2007

PM11:33am

I was completely off grid for three weeks -- phoned up Helen Thomas when I got online again. And she just burst in to tears

11:33 am
PM11:33am

I suspect you didn't cry during my absence Bryce

BE11:33am

Only privately. And I really can't imagine Helen doing that.

PM11:33am

I think it was put on slightly

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Anyway, should we get back to the task in hand? We've another half-hour to get through.

PM11:34am

Sure, if we must

BE11:34am

There's this Diageo tequila thing.

11:34 am
Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,343, down 31.16 (-1.31%), High: 2,368, Low: 2,341, Volume: 1.92m
PM11:34am

More tequila

BE11:34am

An excuse for every single business section to run a picture of George Clooney this morning.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Casamigos. Fear is they're overpaying.

PM11:35am

It is stunning what celebrity endorsement has done to the price tag here

BE11:36am

The idea of super-premium tequila doesn't sit entirely right with me, though I'm prepared to believe that some people like it.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Unike Scotch, I'm thinking it is difficult to know the difference in a shot of tequila after just a couple..

BE11:37am

Hm. The last tequila I had was at the Walkabout in Shepherds Bush, cost £1, and was regretted for some time after.

PM11:37am

And this Casamigos stuff costs£50 a bottle

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Here's the Barclays blurb on it.

BE11:37am

The 170k case brand was founded in 2013 by Rande Gerbe, George Clooney and Mike Meldman and has grown at a 54% CAGR over the last 2 years. The brand is priced at a similar c.$50 a bottle level to Diageo's other super-premium tequila Don Julio. Few financial terms in relation to the transaction have been disclosed, but the group will pay $700m upfront and a potential further $300m by way of a performance-linked earn-out over the next 10 years. Diageo expects the deal to be earning neutral in each of the first 3 years post H2 2017 (calendar) completion and expects it to deliver returns above WACC in year 4.

BE11:37am

Although we see the attractions of the high-growth super-premium tequila category, based on our estimate that Don Julio sells for c. $200 per case, Diageo is paying an EV/sales multiple of c. 20x for Casamigos. This is a full price by any stretch of the imagination and success now depends on Diageo's ability to sustain/accelerate growth without cannibalising Don Julio sales in order to prove its worth. With this far from a given, and with the group still struggling to grow its US business in line with the overall spirits category (due to on-going challenges in vodka), we continue to prefer Pernod Ricard.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

(@GBKrona: fair enough. I'm wrong about lots of things.)

PM11:38am

With these super-brands (gin, vodka, whatever) doesnt the market immediately get swamped?

PM11:39am

ie -- there are now about 50 gins in waitrose priced above £25..

11:39 am
PM11:39am

And so you only ever get tempted if they are on special

BE11:39am

Yes. It's tricky to carve out a spot in the higher ground when the product's pretty generic and the only differentiation is price.

BE11:40am

Also marketing, I guess.

11:40 am
PM11:40am

The Scotch industry has managed it (but its not pretty generic) -- and I guess there is Grey Goose

PM11:40am

SIxsmith, i guess as well

BE11:41am

Vodka's the worst. There's literally no difference between them. Absolutely none.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Anyway, here's Jefferies, which draws a comparison between tequila and baby milk.

BE11:41am

Bear with it.

BE11:41am

Being more like RB is partly about more cost discipline, but it is also about agility and allocation of capital, with RB having spent the last 10 years repositioning towards higher growth and margin categories. The acquisition of Casamigos is a decisive step to accelerate growth in high end tequila. In our report, we see upside of as much as 50% from being more like RB.

11:41 am
BE11:42am

RB being Reckitt.

BE11:42am

The acquisition complements the existing Don Julio brand and we see a low risk of cannibalisation with Don Julio viewed as a high quality, connoisseurs liquid, and Casamigos a more lifestyle ("friends and fun") brand with a greater weighting to female consumers. With Don Julio volumes 450k cases and Casamigos 170k, this offers a stronger portfolio to scale up vs Patron (2.2m
cases). Over the med-term, there are opportunities to widen distribution beyond the USA (99% sales).

BE11:42am

Being more like RB is in part about more cost discipline, but it is also about agility and allocation of capital, with RB having spent the last 10 years repositioning the portfolio towards higher growth and margin categories. The acquisition is a decisive step by Diageo to accelerate growth in high end tequila and reposition the business towards higher growth opportunities. It supports our view about Diageo being more like RB.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(@Boncoeur: scotch has some variable in terms of taste but is still a massive con. Training the public to value a single malt as better than blended, which is objectively better at much lower prices, was marketing genius.)

BE11:44am

Financial impact – EPS neutral in first three years, does not impact decision around share buyback: Diageo have stated that they expect the acquisition to be EPS neutral for the first three years and will make an economic profit in year 4 (WACC 8%). With a transaction cost of £551m ($700m), the deal would increase FY18E net debt to EBITDA a modest 0.1x to 2.1x. Therefore, we believe it does not impact Diageo’s financial flexibility & decision making on share buybacks.

PM11:44am

(Bryce!)

11:45 am
PM11:46am

(Are you genuinely arguing that any old blended scotch is 'better than say an unpeated Bruichladdich ???)

BE11:46am

(No, it's not a blanket claim. Obviously, some single malts are better than many blendeds. But whisky isn't superior just because it's single malt. That's nonsense.)

PM11:47am

(Ok)

11:46 am
PM11:47am

(ish)

BE11:47am

(Blind tests are the only way to cut through all this. And once in the blindfold, anyone who claims to prefer a bottle of £45 Speyside 12yr to a £20 Monkey Shoulder is lying.)

undefined
11:48 am
PM11:48am

I'm out of the loop

PM11:48am

But Cloudbuy

PM11:48am

What's Mark Dixon suddenly doing on the share register

11:48 am
PM11:48am

??

PM11:48am

He's got five percent

PM11:48am

http://www.investe...1706220730018443I/

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Dixon of Regus, of course

PM11:49am

Well, I'm assuming that!

BE11:49am

Oh? News to me. Dixon slotted a load of IWG earlier in the week, of course.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

IWG being the renamed Regus.

BE11:50am

No idea what he's doing in this. Is he on the board?

PM11:50am

I can't find any discussion of this

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Will look into it later

Cloudbuy PLC (CBUY:LSE): Last: 3.19, up 0.19 (+6.33%), Volume: 197.21k
undefined
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Let me see if there's any sellside to fill the last ten minutes.

BE11:52am

The ROTR have disappeared into arguing about whisky so we can make our own entertainment on this side of the page.

BE11:53am

Reckitt, mentioned earlier in passing, gets a downgrade from SocGen.

11:53 am
Reckitt Benckiser Group PLC (RB.:LSE): Last: 7,834, down 44 (-0.56%), High: 7,884, Low: 7,794, Volume: 314.15k
BE11:54am

Mostly valuation.

BE11:54am

RB now trades in line with Global Consumer Staples on 20.5x 2018e P/E. Consumer Health and Infant Nutrition are structurally fast-growing, high-gross-margin categories and RB’s cash conversion and management team are best in class. However, near-term headwinds from Scholl remain and we think RB will struggle to achieve a premium to the sector until these are resolved. We think the shares could pause for breath and downgrade to Hold.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

There's also Stifel pushing SIG.

SIG PLC (SHI:LSE): Last: 149.90, up 4.5 (+3.09%), High: 151.90, Low: 148.50, Volume: 1.80m
BE11:56am

After a challenging two years we see considerable potential for a recovery. We are impressed by the new management team and expect it to utilise its wealth of turnaround experience to improve operational execution, drive efficiencies and build on SIG’s market-leading positions. Whilst markets will remain competitive we see limited downside to depressed earnings with leverage reduction a key near-term catalyst to improving sentiment. We upgrade to Buy with a TP of 170p, valuing SIG on 12x recovered EPS of 14p.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

As previously commented we view SIG’s issues as primarily self-inflicted with the specialist distribution model still relevant given the group’s significant market shares in core verticals and geographies. As such we view a return to normalised through-the-cycle margins (5% UK&I, 4% Cont. Europe) as viable through a re-focusing on sales and improved efficiency through consolidating the group’s decentralised structure. A scenario with low-single digit sales growth and recovered medium-term margins (FY19E) would drive EPS of 14p. We view this as more appropriate for valuing the group than current depressed earnings. Whilst we view the normalised margins in this scenario as attainable, we take a more cautious approach in our published forecasts at this early juncture.

BE11:57am

Near term we see limited downside risk to depressed earnings, whilst progress on leverage reduction would improve market sentiment. We upgrade with our eyes wide open – markets remain competitive and elevated leverage limits investment potential. Despite this, management’s experience, SIG’s market positioning and multiple levers for margin accretion give us confidence in this nascent turnaround.

BE11:58am

Oh, and sector wise there's a mining wrap from Liberum that some folk seem to be interested in.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Bearish.

BE11:58am

In the past month as commodity prices have fallen the UK
Mining sector has moved back into marked-to-market
(MtM) downgrade territory for the first time since January
2016. Analysing consensus data over the past four years
using two separate methodologies shows the inflection
point from MtM upgrade to MtM downgrade territory
typically lags turning points in the equities (4 months late
here), but is still a strong predictor of returns over the
medium term. Remain underweight Miners.

BE11:58am

The Mining sector is cyclical and by
virtue of this, MtM downgrade /
upgrade models have been a good
predictor of performance. Lagging
(arguably over-optimistic) upgrades
and recently falling commodity prices
sees the sector back in downgrade
territory for the first time in 18
months. We expect earnings
momentum will fall further below
consensus in the second half.
